chapter.title: Developing a simple JSP web application
chapter.para: In this you'll find out how to create a simple JSP application using the Red Hat Developer Studio. The application will show a classic "Hello World!" on the page.

We'll assume that you have already launched Red Hat Developer Studio and also that the Red Hat perspective is the current perspective. (If not, make it active by selecting Window/Open Perspective/Red Hat Developer Studio from the menu bar or by selecting Window/ Open Perspective/Other... from the menu bar and then selecting Red Hat Developer Studio from the Select Perspective dialog box.)

section.title: Setting Up the Project
section.para: At first a new project for the application will be created.

listitem.para: Go to the menu bar and select File/New/Project...
Select Web/Dynamic Web Project in the New Project dialog box
Leave everything else as is, and click Finish

section.para: A jspHello node should appear in the upper-left Package Explorer view.

section.title: Creating JSP Page
section.para: In our simple application we need to create only one JSP page which displays a "Hello World!" message.

listitem.para: Type "hello.jsp" for file name and click Next button.

section.para: In the next window you can choose a template for your jsp page and see its preview.

listitem.para: Select "New JSP File (xhtml)" template and click Finish button.

section.para: Our hello.jsp page will now appear in Project Explorer.

section.title: Web.xml File
section.para: When you are creating web project the wizard creates the web.xml for you automatically. The web.xml file editor provided by Red Hat Developer Studio is available in two modes: design and source.
Both modes are fully synchronized. Let's add mapping to our hello.jsp page in web.xml file.
If you come back to design mode you will see that the changes made are automatically reflected in that mode.
Actually you don't really need any config right now. You can clear the web.xml file, save it and you'll still be able to launch your application.

section.title: Deploying the project
section.para: While creating any web project you could experience a pain writing ant scripts and managing the packaging even if a developer is writing the most trivial web applications. With Red Hat Developer Studio you are saved from such a pain. All you need is start JBoss server and launch your application in your favorite browser.
You can also create a war archive with RHDS's Archive Tools and export it to any web server.

section.para: RHDS comes with JSP design-time preview features. When designing JSP pages you can easily preview how they will look during runtime. You can even attach your stylesheet to the preview.

section.title: Launch JSP Project
section.para: Let's now launch our project on server. We'll use JBoss server that is shiped with Red Hat Developer Studio.

listitem.para: Start JBoss server from JBoss Server view by clicking the Start icon.

Click the Run icon or right click your project folder and select Run on Server. If you haven't made any changes in web.xml file or cleared it out you can launch the application by right clicking the hello.jsp page and selecting Run on the Server.
